name: The Bible Tells Me So Online Quiz | The Bible | 10 Questions

questions.text: The Bible tells me that who 'walked with God and was not'? (Genesis 5, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Enoch.

	Enoch was the great grandfather of Noah. He was three hundred and sixty five years old when God took him to Heaven. Enoch didn't die like humans do. He was walking with God one day and God took him to Heaven.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that this particular river is described as 'the great river'. (Genesis 2, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Euphrates.

	The origin of the Euphrates River is in the Armenian mountains; it runs for 1700 miles to empty into the Persian Gulf. The Lord promised Abraham that his children would control all the land from the river in Egypt to the Euphrates River. Genesis 2:14 (KJV) is the first book of the Bible to mention the Euphrates River. The verse mentions the Euphrates River being a river of paradise.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that Paul referred to the people of Galatia as 'foolish'. (Galatians 3, KJV)
questions.explanation:
True.

	Paul's sermon to the Galatians began by calling them foolish for not believing that Jesus Christ had been crucified for their sins. Paul believed that they were turning away from God by walking with the unbelievers instead of listening to what God had to say.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that the 'most humble man on earth' was none other than which man?  (Numbers 12, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Moses.

	Moses was born to Jochebed and Amram in the land of Goshen. He was taken in by the Pharoah's daughter and raised as her son. He died on top of Mount Nebo at the age of one-hundred and twenty. In Numbers, God referred to him as the most humble man on earth and stated that there was no other prophet like Moses.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that Er was '______ in the sight of the Lord'. (Genesis 38, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Wicked.

	Er was the grandson of Jacob and Leah and a husband of Tamar. Not much is known about Er other than the Lord killed him because of his wickedness.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that John the Baptist referred to which two groups of people as a 'generation of vipers'? (Matthew 3, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Pharisees and Sadducees.

	John the Baptist was beginning a baptism when he saw some Pharisees and Sadducees in the crowd. Stopping the baptism, John the Baptist publicly denounced the two groups by calling them a generation of vipers. The Gospel of Luke has John the Baptist having the same encounter with the Pharisees and Sadducees, but in Luke John the Baptist is speaking to the public while in Matthew John the Baptist is pointing at the Pharisees and Sadducees.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that David's son _______ was 'wiser than all men'. (I Kings 4, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Solomon.

	God had given Solomon many riches and made him wiser than all men. I Kings illustrates this point by adding that Solomon was wiser than Ethan, Herman, Calcol, and Darda. Solomon spoke three thousand proverbs and wrote one thousand and five songs. People from miles around came to hear Solomon speak just so they could hear his wisdom.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that who was a 'mighty hunter before the Lord'? (Genesis 10, KJV)
questions.explanation:
Nimrod.

	Nimrod was the son of Cush, the grandson of Ham, and the great grandson of Noah. The Bible described him as a mighty hunter before the Lord. Nimrod established his kingdom in Shinar and helped erect the Tower of Babel.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that 'his own works were evil; and his brother's righteous'. (I John 3, KJV). Who were the two brothers spoken of in this book?
questions.explanation:
Cain; Abel.

	I John 3 is addressed to the children of God and how believers as children of God should love one another and not act out of jealousy as Cain did to Abel when Cain killed his brother.

questions.text: The Bible tells me that Job was described as '_______ and _______' and 'feared God'. (Job 1, KJV) What are the missing words?
questions.explanation:
Perfect and upright.

	In the first verse, Job is described as perfect and upright. Even after his home and family was destroyed, Job kept his faith in God and was rewarded with more than what he had before his tragedies.
